misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Computer understands (or needs) English prompts / prompts affect input
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that printing prompts like "Enter size:" and "Enter elements:" is part of how the program reads the input (or that the computer/autograder needs these words to know what comes next).
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `System.out.print(...)` only writes characters to the output stream for a human to see. It does not change what `Scanner` reads, and the computer does not “interpret” these English messages to decide what to read next. `Scanner` reads based purely on the input stream and the method calls (`nextInt()`, etc.). In some grading setups, extra prompt text can even cause a “wrong output” despite correct logic, because the grader compares exact output text.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Usually no runtime/compile error; potential "wrong answer" in automated grading due to extra output text. Conceptually, it reflects a shaky model of I/O (mixing up output prompts with input parsing).
